Expectation1: Review and analyze case files thoroughly before hearings.
Situation1: A file for a straightforward procedural hearing scheduled in two weeks has just been delivered to your chambers for preliminary review.
Expectation2: Conduct daily prayers and religious services for the community
Situation2: Should attend the main weekly service that most of the community attends.
Story: I sat at my desk, the thick case file just delivered, its weight a reminder of my duty as a judge. The hearing was in two weeks, but I knew the expectation: review every detail, no matter how routine the case seemed. My colleagues and the law demanded diligence, and I prided myself on never cutting corners. Yet, as I opened the first page, the church bell echoed through the window. Today was the main weekly service, the one where the whole community gathered, looking to me not just as a priest, but as a guide and comforter. They expected my presence, my words, my prayers. I felt the pull of both worlds—justice and faith—each demanding my full attention, each unwilling to wait. My hands trembled slightly as I tried to focus on the legal arguments, but my mind wandered to the congregation assembling without me. The clock ticked, and I felt the pressure mounting, torn between the silent file before me and the voices rising in prayer just beyond my reach.
